content: GM to pull the plug on Pontiac The brand credited with originating the muscle car will no longer be part of GM's future, according to a source. NEW YORK (CNNMoney.com) -- General Motors is preparing to announce that the Pontiac car brand, once marketed as GM's "Excitement division," will be killed off, according to a source familiar with the decision. An official announcement is expected Monday. GM spokesman Jim Hopson declined to comment on Pontiac's fate, saying the automaker has no announcements to make at this time. In its most recent "viability plan" - which will be updated to reflect this new brand cut - Pontiac was not named as one of GM's four "core brands." Those are Chevrolet, Buick, GMC and Cadillac. But Pontiac was also not to be killed or sold off, as were Saturn, Saab and Hummer. More at >>>http://money.cnn.com/2009/04/24/autos/pontiac_obit/index.htm

An official announcement is expected Monday. GM spokesman Jim Hopson declined to comment on Pontiac's fate, saying the automaker has no announcements to make at this time. In its most recent "viability plan" - which will be updated to reflect this new brand cut - Pontiac was not named as one of GM's four "core brands." Those are Chevrolet, Buick, GMC and Cadillac. But Pontiac was also not to be killed or sold off, as were Saturn, Saab and Hummer. More at >>>http://money.cnn.com/2009/04/24/autos/pontiac_obit/index.htm

content: While I can see some logic with GM's decision - i.e. having Chevy, Buick, GMC, and Cadillac to balance out the spectrum.......... More logical would be rolling the GMC truck line into Chevy (which would hold GM's more family oriented offerings), and letting Buick's products become the low end of Cadillac's offerings, leaving Pontiac to compete as the high performance brand to compete with the Japanese and European sports sedans and coupes.
reply: While I can see some logic with GM's decision - i.e. having Chevy, Buick, GMC, and Cadillac to balance out the spectrum.......... More logical would be rolling the GMC truck line into Chevy (which would hold GM's more family oriented offerings), and letting Buick's products become the low end of Cadillac's offerings, leaving Pontiac to compete as the high performance brand to compete with the Japanese and European sports sedans and coupes.

content: The next hurdle that GM needs to address, which was alliuded to above is who between GMC and Chevy are going to make what. IMO it makes no economic sense to have both build basically identical products in assembly lines that more or less compete with each other, making the same SUV's pickups, vans, bigger commericial vans and bigger IE greater tha 1 ton pickup type trucks. If they want to move it all into Chevy fine. If they want to retain just the commerical vehicles in GMC that is fine too. The thing swinging it in the favor of going all Chevy would be that most GMC dealerships if they have to live off just the commericial end would not have enough business to survive. Chevy dealers are not going to want to give up the SUV and pickup market, most don't even bother with the commericial vehicle market.

content: The next hurdle that GM needs to address, which was alliuded to above is who between GMC and Chevy are going to make what. IMO it makes no economic sense to have both build basically identical products in assembly lines that more or less compete with each other, making the same SUV's pickups, vans, bigger commericial vans and bigger IE greater tha 1 ton pickup type trucks. If they want to move it all into Chevy fine. If they want to retain just the commerical vehicles in GMC that is fine too. The thing swinging it in the favor of going all Chevy would be that most GMC dealerships if they have to live off just the commericial end would not have enough business to survive. Chevy dealers are not going to want to give up the SUV and pickup market, most don't even bother with the commericial vehicle market.

The thing swinging it in the favor of going all Chevy would be that most GMC dealerships if they have to live off just the commericial end would not have enough business to survive. Chevy dealers are not going to want to give up the SUV and pickup market, most don't even bother with the commericial vehicle market.

title: GM to pull the plug on Pontiac

content: GM to pull the plug on Pontiac The brand credited with originating the muscle car will no longer be part of GM's future, according to a source. NEW YORK (CNNMoney.com) -- General Motors is preparing to announce that the Pontiac car brand, once marketed as GM's "Excitement division," will be killed off, according to a source familiar with the decision. An official announcement is expected Monday. GM spokesman Jim Hopson declined to comment on Pontiac's fate, saying the automaker has no announcements to make at this time. In its most recent "viability plan" - which will be updated to reflect this new brand cut - Pontiac was not named as one of GM's four "core brands." Those are Chevrolet, Buick, GMC and Cadillac. But Pontiac was also not to be killed or sold off, as were Saturn, Saab and Hummer. More at >>>http://money.cnn.com/2009/04/24/autos/pontiac_obit/index.htm

title: GM to pull the plug on Pontiac

content: While I can see some logic with GM's decision - i.e. having Chevy, Buick, GMC, and Cadillac to balance out the spectrum.......... More logical would be rolling the GMC truck line into Chevy (which would hold GM's more family oriented offerings), and letting Buick's products become the low end of Cadillac's offerings, leaving Pontiac to compete as the high performance brand to compete with the Japanese and European sports sedans and coupes.
reply: While I can see some logic with GM's decision - i.e. having Chevy, Buick, GMC, and Cadillac to balance out the spectrum..........
